## Github

### Forking the Stat 545 Book
We are going to copy the stat 545 book
1. Goto the [stat 545](https://github.com/rstudio-education/stat545) page
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/Github.png")
```
2.Hit the button in the upper right corner, that says fork
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/Github_fork.png")
```
3.Go to your copy of stat 545
4.Hit clone or download
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/Github_link.png")
```
5.Go into Rstudio and create a new github project
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/New_project.png")
```
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/Version_Control.png")
```
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/R_git.png")
```
6.paste the link from your github fork into the Repository URL and hit create project.
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/R_git_url.png")
```
7. At the bottom of your screen there should be a terminal and console, the console speaks R, and the terminal spearks Linux. This means that the terminal can run github commands
```{r R-vs-RStudio-1, echo=FALSE, fig.align='center', out.width='95%', purl=FALSE}

knitr::include_graphics("images/Terminal.png")
```
